results.title: Amy
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Amy is a 16 year-old aboriginal girl from the country now living in Sydney. She faces many problems at school, in getting a job, and in the community because of her colour. Photography by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: Aborigines in the Alice
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Looks at two problems facing aborigines in Alice Springs - child care and alcoholism. In 1970 the death rate among Aboriginal children rose to nearly 1 in 5, one of the highest infant mortality rates in the world. Today the ratio has improved, but Aboriginal health still presents a grim picture. Interviews people concerned. Reporter: Brian King; Photographer: Richard Bailie-Mace; Sound: Peter Lipscomb.

results.title: Grace Tame visits the Prime Minister
results.brief_description: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. In this footage captured by Channel 7 cameraperson Pete Wilkinson during her visit to Government House, Tame made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony-faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which went viral in this tweet from SBS reporter Pablo Vinales and whipped conservative commentators into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

Meanwhile, a huge swath of the internet came out in support of Tame’s directness – with stills from the footage shared across social media – likening her demeanour to their feelings towards the Coalition government.

Throughout her tenure as Australian of the Year, Tame has been vocal about the government’s handling of sexual abuse allegations and its treatment of survivors. In April of 2021, when asked about Scott Morrison’s ‘as a father’ response to rape allegations made by Brittany Higgins – which some believe he didn’t take seriously until “viewing it from the lens of being a father of daughters” – Tame responded: “It shouldn’t take children to have a conscience. And actually, on top of that, having children doesn’t guarantee a conscience.” Like this most recent interaction with the Prime Minister, that clip also went viral on the internet, helping solidify Tame’s position as a courageous advocate for sexual assault survivors and a moral champion at a time when many see Australia’s leaders as lacking both courage and morals.

As Imogen Champagne writes in Crikey:, “Conservatives have been trying to silence Grace Tame all year. Now she’s finally given them silence and they can’t shut up about it.”
description_for_label: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: FAWN
results.brief_description: FAWN connects characters from popular culture with everyday people who have the lived experience of losing a parent. Dressed in a kind of orphan drag and performing acts of care on each other, they form temporary bonds and act out unlikely intimacies. FAWN queers the notion of family and acknowledges that loss doesn’t always lead to a heroic coming of age adventure.

results.title: Scripture for a smoke screen: Episode 1 – dolphin house
results.creator_credit: Luke Smith, Zoe Theodore and Amrita Hepi
results.brief_description:
“I’m interested in exploring the gulf between lived experience and its representation, and how identity and ideas around intelligence are constantly being shaped, amplified or flattened through the experience of surveillance and misidentification.”

In the 1960s, scientists tried to talk to dolphins. The experiment was backed by NASA, who were investigating ways to communicate with extra-terrestrial life. One intelligence test attempted to determine self-awareness by seeing if the dolphins recognised themselves in a mirror.

Amrita Hepi draws on that trial in “Scripture for a smokescreen: Episode 1 – dolphin house”, seemingly seducing her own image. She dances with an inflatable dolphin, attempting to communicate with it through voice and movement, paralleling the intimacy between one of the researchers, Margaret Lovatt, and a male dolphin during the experiment.

Not only does Amrita lampoon the absurdity of teaching marine mammals English, she uses the study to expose the way Western knowledge systems – language, ethics and science – are imposed on people and cultures through colonisation. Through choreographed dance and moving image, Amrita explores what happens when we’re constantly under surveillance, and when assumptions about us are presented to the world through someone else’s viewpoint.

Amrita Hepi is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery

constellations_primary.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_primary.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

results.description:
“I’m interested in exploring the gulf between lived experience and its representation, and how identity and ideas around intelligence are constantly being shaped, amplified or flattened through the experience of surveillance and misidentification.”

In the 1960s, scientists tried to talk to dolphins. The experiment was backed by NASA, who were investigating ways to communicate with extra-terrestrial life. One intelligence test attempted to determine self-awareness by seeing if the dolphins recognised themselves in a mirror.

Amrita Hepi draws on that trial in Scripture for a smokescreen: Episode 1 – dolphin house, seemingly seducing her own image. She dances with an inflatable dolphin, attempting to communicate with it through voice and movement, paralleling the intimacy between one of the researchers, Margaret Lovatt, and a male dolphin, Peter, during the experiment.

Not only does Amrita lampoon the absurdity of teaching marine mammals English, she uses the study to expose the way Western knowledge systems – language, ethics and science – are imposed on people and cultures through colonisation. Through choreographed dance and moving image, Amrita explores what happens when we’re constantly under surveillance, and when assumptions about us are presented to the world through someone else’s viewpoint.

Amrita Hepi is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery

results.title: Louder than words
results.brief_description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.
results.description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.

results.title: Payback
results.creator_credit: Penny McDonald, Warwick Thornton and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description: Paddy, an old aboriginal man, has been in jail for twenty years. It is the day of his release. Paddy knows of two laws - white law and black law. The twenty years he has spent doing time for the white man’s law has been in preparation for this one - his payback day.
